Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2008 07:24PM Little-G wrote: I just wanted to say that I TOTALLY get not wanting to deal with this crap anymore!!!  And the never ending tests!!  I feel the same way,it really weighs me down mentally.  But, I had this thought this evening, as I just got home from yet another test today, and was standing next to my fireplace warming up, and going over my conversation with the tech and I said "yeah, its been 2 years of this" 2 years!!!  wow!!  of never ending tests.  What have I been doing in between time?  I don't know.  I guess my point is that it does suck, and if we have to go thru it, we better be doing something good in between time!!  Have the good cry and then remember to enjoy the in between times.  Maybe my own rant here, but I hope you get something out of it.  And I am sending nothing but positive thoughts your way on the scan!!!!!!  Let me know how you do OK? g
Posts.Title: I'm upset, marker came up high, need Pet Scan Desny iodine

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2008 05:12PM Little-G wrote: Hi Badboob, Speaking for myself, as an "early stage patient" I think I understand as much as anyone else does about what the chemo and the rads are for.  I get the idea that they are to get those stray cells that may be floating about.  But even you said none of these are a cure.  I guess some of us here wonder why should we put ourselves thru chemo and rads and tamox (or whatever it may be) if there is no conclusive proof that these toxins will work for us?  Many women on the boards did do everything they were told to do, and still it came back.  And visa versa.  I guess that's the great debate.  For some of us, having to deal with the SE's in hopes that it caught that stray cell, just sounds wrong.  But..we as individuals we have to live with whatever choice we make.  I do agree with you that you shouldn't look back and say "oh..I wish I would have done ______."  However, I think that's human nature too.  Much luck to you and I hope you are well today. g
Posts.Title: Informal Poll re:recurrences SISKimberly SISKimberly

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2008 02:31PM Little-G wrote: Kimberly, I think this is a great question and one that plenty of us wonder about.  My feelings are that they really do not know what is helpful and what is not to us as individuals, and so the suggest route is given in hopes it will help.  Just my thoughts again.  I think we all know the answers given here are not scientific, and that no one should base their tx on it.  They are individual results.  That being my point.  Can they really say what is helpful, when each of us varies so much from the other?  But..it is interesting to know.  g

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2008 04:42PM Little-G wrote: This is one of my biggest pet peeves!!  Bogus claims processing and canceling people!!  We ALL need to stay on top of this in our own corners of the world.  If we ease up on them at all, they will walk all over us!  Don't let them disregard any of our bills or procedures.  I am making it a mission to go thru all the bills I had last year and to make sure each and everyone was paid out as it should be.  I have a feeling I will find inaccuracies.  I use to work for an ins. company, and I know what goes on there.  So...this law suit was long over due for all of us!!!! g

Posts.Title: tumor markers- how much attention do you pay to them? melmedic06 hazelnut

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2008 09:51PM Little-G wrote: Hi LuAnn,  I think the letter is great!  I hope someone takes the time to read thru it all.  Shorter might make them read the entire thing, but your letter says it all.  I happen to be one of those peittite women that kept her hair, and her looks and "looks" no worse for the ware and was dx at stage 1.  But mentally......I am alot worse.  This has taken a toll on me and my family.  I am not dancing thru a meadow with butterflys and living as I did before BC.  I think I get alot of resentment from some of the other moms at my kids sports because I don't have the energy to do things like I did, and this has been hard on me and my kids.  But..since I look like I did before, I think they assume I am fine and probably think I'm slacking.  I don't really care anymore, I think I have moved beyond all that crap, but you are on target with your letter.  People do need to know that this has had a real impact on us.  Some ,more than others, but still a life changing event.  I doubt any of us go back to "normal."  So..I applaude you as well, and I hope someone picks up your letter and sits down and reads it!!  g
Posts.Title: Long, but need your opinion LuAnnH mom2acat

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2008 06:33PM Little-G wrote: Carol,  I got a chuckle out of the "Oh no, not the positive thing again!"  Yes, I agree.  It gets really hard some days to remain positive, dosn't it?  I am doing the race for the cure again, tomorrow.  Mainly for my son.  I think he sees all the pink shirts and realizes that there are alot of kids in his shoes too.  And that moms do go on, and there is life after BC.  So..I do it for him.  My friend, who also was dx with BC a  year ago, is not doing the race this year. She is fed up with all the pink as well.  And feels that Komen can do more than they are.  I agree in some ways, but in others I think, well..at least its out there and people take some notice.  LuAnn's letter is great, as it gives an idea of what most of us go thru.  I hope too that someone takes notice.  I guess the point of my post is that I understand being burnt on all of this stuff, but we need to stay pro-active and make people see what's going on.  BTW...I did not see that issue of People...wow.  In that respect, I think it really does give people the idea that cancer is no big deal.  OK..I'm conflicted on everything I just said!!  :-) g

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 06:10PM Little-G wrote: galnok - thanks for "getting it"  I feel guilt too over unnecessary bills.  My GP is out today and tomorrow.  I still have some bills that I'm paying off, but most are paid right now.  I didn't call my onc.  Shirlann- hopefully your computer is back to "normal."  I'm having printer issues today so I feel for you! :-)  I don't think I'm under severe stress, but who knows.  I did wonder the other night if it was heart attack or not.  So, the symtoms did make me think of that.  Anniee - the heavy coughing has stopped for about 2 weeks now.  Just some coughing.  Mostly a dry cough, and no, it dosn't hurt more if I breathe deep.  It just hurts.  My lung nodule hasn't been checked for probably about a year now.  I think.  I'm not on any meds.  Thank you to all of you!!!  And..of course I know this is stuff I should be telling my doctor. I just don't seem to be able to pick up that phone.  :-(  In my head I keep saying "I'm sure its nothing" but everytime it hurts I wonder what it is.  I'm conflicted.  Hhhmmm...that's nothing new for me.  Thank you again!!  And any other input is always welcome!!! g

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2008 11:40AM Little-G wrote: Hi Krissy, I'm sorry you have to go thru this.  This is a great site for information and support, so I'm glad you found us.  Radiation does act different on some people.  For myself, I did get burned, but it was do-able.  I put aloe on everytime I got done.  Physically I was very tired, but I did work thru the entire 7 weeks.  As far as a size difference, I don't notice any.  But..I have implants, I had them before I was ever dx.  So, it could be the reason that I don't see any difference.  I don't know.  The radiation effects seem to linger, even after 2 years.  You're not being paranoid in asking.  You should know as much about it as you can, and make sure you are making the right decision for yourself.  Anything I can help you with, feel free to ask or send me a pm.  I wish you the best thru this!! g
Posts.Title: Scared & anxious about radiation! -Any comments please! Krissy37 snowyday

Posts.Content: Little-G wrote: Hi Ladies, I really need some advice, although in my head I think I know what everyone will say.  I had bronchitis in the begining of Feb.  went on antibiotics got better for a couple of days then it came back.  Went on antibiotics again.  The cough has went down alot and my voice is back.  But..I am having chest pain for the last couple of weeks.  It's like a burning feeling in my chest.  I called my GP today and he's out, the nurse told me to call my oncologist.  Where I get stuck is that I just got done paying tons of medical bills from last year.  Now my deductible starts all over again.  And..I feel like a baby for calling because I think he'll send me for some test, and then it will turn out to be nothing and I will have wasted money and time, and feel stupid.  I know that whole thought is stupid, I just can't seem to get past this.  I had a lung nodule when first dx, but last checked it was stable.  I guess I'm just afraid, and at the same time think its nothing, and why am I being a big baby about it??  Sorry to go on...I'm stuck.  I just need some help.  I bought this up to friend, but she dosn't get it.  I know someone here will.  It messes me up even thinking about all of this.  Thanks for any and ALL advice!! g Dx 2005, ILC, 1cm, Stage IB, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Dear Lord, I just scheduled brain surgery AlaskaDeb heymoose

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2008 06:35AM Little-G wrote: I attend Komen committee meetings every now and then in Portland, OR.  They do have a list you can see of where the local money is going.  I'm not sure if they hand it out, but you can call and see.  I have ran the race for the last few years and raised a bit of money with my co-captain, who was also dx with BC, I asked her this year if we were going to run again as a team and she is suspect like some of you.  Her issue was someone emailed her to buy M&M's as they were giving a few cents on each packet they sold to Komen, however sugar is linked to BC, so she was/is upset about that. She wonders how they can put there name on cancer causing products, much like the paraban that was mentioned.  I am undecided.  I guess I agree they could be doing more with the amount that is raised each year just from the run alone.  I think if you want to see some changes you might consider calling your local Komen foundation and attending some of the meetings.  The Portland group is very receptive and do go out of their way to get your questions answered.  All that aside, I think we need more avenues to help some of the "survivors" out.  There's not enought out there for people who are already in a tight spot.  g
Posts.Title: Is anyone getting help from Komen? pinkpig fire

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2009 02:06PM Little-G wrote: Sheila, Thanks so much for the post. My problem is that I am self insured and my deducitble is $5000, none of which I have met for this year.  I haven't had a mammo or breast MRI for almost 2 years now.  Since I was dx with ILC, the mammo never picked it up, so the onc. recommended MRI.  But with the economy tanking, I just can't afford it.  I am frustrated.  I have a hard time when it comes to doctors.  I'd rather not see them.   But when I can't stand for more than an hour, and my hips and spine are hurting, I think I finally need to find out what it is.  And then for them to tell me maybe I dont' need to see the onc anymore.  I don't get it.

Posts.Title: Symptom Question Little-G Little-G

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2008 12:13AM Little-G wrote: Hi Ladies, Well, I broke down and called my onc's office today.  They are in the middle of a move, so what a freakin nightmare it was to get anywhere with them today.  They moved my appt. up to next week from Feb. and they scheduled me for an ultra sound tomorrow.  The nurse said it didn't sound like lymphodema ?  I told them it was hurting me more and more every day, and also my underarm and my boob are now hurting me too.  So, they'll call me tomorrow to set up PT.  I think if I wouldn't have pushed them, they would have just let me ride until Feb.  But, with all the talk of lymphodema, and what it can turn into, it freaked me out.  So..maybe I'll know something tomorrow?  I hope so.  g
Posts.Title: Symptom Question Little-G Little-G

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2008 08:37PM Little-G wrote: Well, the good news is that the US came out negative.  But..I didn't really understand why they sent me for that anyway??  It just didn't make sense to me.  I'm waiting for the PT to call me to schedule a time to be evaluated to see if maybe its LE (I learned that shorthand from Binney :-)  And my GP wants to order an MRI.  I guess I'll see.  It is still hurting and there is still that lump.  g
Posts.Title: Symptom Question Little-G Little-G

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2008 10:34PM Little-G wrote: Hi Annemarie, I agree, that we are all different and hard to say how you will do.  I was always physically active and I had 7 weeks of rads (that was almost 2 years ago).  I did OK.  I worked thru the entire 7 weeks and did pretty much what I always did.  I may have went to bed a little earlier.  That being said...I probably over did.  If I had to do it again I would make sure to take advantage of that time and get the rest I should have taken, and also took up people on their offers to do things.  I have never felt "normal" so far, after having the 7 weeks of rads.  So...don't play "superman" and get your rest!!  :-) g

Posts.Title: Another Sister Has Earned Her Wings LauraGTO ilenee

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2008 02:27PM Little-G wrote: We all know this is easier said then done, but try not to worry to much.  You said its a "lumpy area", so not a hard lump you can feel?  Before I found my lump I use to always wonder what it would feel like anyway?  How could I tell the differance?  Well, I did!  I knew as soon as I felt it what it was.  It was very definite.  Maybe what you're feeling is just a normal lumpy breast?  I hope that is the case.  Try and do things to keep busy until your mammo.  And don't think about it being cancer.  Again, easier said then done, but it could be like the other ladies were saying, and not cancer.  The least likely would be that it is cancer.  Try and go with that, and let us know how it turns out OK?  My thoughts are with you! g
Posts.Title: worried... momto1 iodine

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2009 01:20PM Little-G wrote: Hi Ladies, I don't post much, but I read thru this thread and thought maybe I'd give it a try and see if anyone has any input for me.  It's a long story, so I'm going to shorten it alot.  I haven't seen my onc. in over a year. Last time I did he took an MRI which showed a herniated disc.  Seen my GP for it and he said there's nothing we can do, other than PT, which my ins. doesn't cover and he let me know my white cell counts were down.  That was in March.  Anyway, the pain has got progressively worse and the other night I was out dancing, and my legs just went out.  I felt it coming, I couldn't stand anymore.  I called my onc. about a month ago (before this) and they were suppose to call me back to make an appt.  I called again today to let them know and she said maybe I didn't need to see the onc. anymore and I should call the GP.  Sorry so long...I just have no idea what to do.  Maybe post this somewhere else?
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2009 02:26PM Little-G wrote: Seyla..No, no meds for BC.  It's a long story, like all of ours.  I refused chemo when dx.  I did do the 7 weeks of rads and have my ovaries out, I was pre-menopausal.  I refused the tamox.  I got a lot of grief on the boards for this in the beginning which is why I didn't post that much regarding my tx.  But we're all different, and we all have to decide which way to go.  I don't regret any of my choices.  Like most of us, there was to much thrown at me at once.  I guess I can't ignore the symptoms anymore is all.  And it may be a disc issue and not cancer at all.  I'm frustrated at the lack of answers and I don't know where to turn is all.  If the nurse dosn't call me back again, I'll fight it another day.  Thanks to all that gave me advice.

Posts.Title: Symptom Question Little-G Little-G

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2008 06:17AM Little-G wrote: I have never had tumor markers.  How does your mom feel about it?  I only get PET and CT if I am having some sort of symptoms.  Talk to your mom too on this and see what her thoughts are.  My dad had lung cancer and I use to go with him to his doctors too.   I wish I had known more at the time.  It's really hard when you don't know what to ask, and what's to be expected.  I wish you and your mom much luck thru this!  This board is a great place to start! g
Posts.Title: Tumor markers - HELP sarika_for_mama LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2008 07:08PM Little-G wrote: Yeah, it gets to be a huge drag!!!  And you start feeling like a hypochondriac.  And then in the back of your head, you think, hmmm, what if it is something.  And then it goes around and around and next thing you think you should be in a rubber room somewhere!! :-)  Nice to know I'm not alone in that.  Not that I wish us to be in a rubber room, but maybe for a couple of days with some martini's wouldn't be a bad thing!  Let me know what you find out OK?  I'll let you know what I find out too.  I think I have my next appt. next month.  Although, really, if it starts hurting any more than it already is, I may break down and call! g
Posts.Title: Symptom Question Little-G Little-G

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2008 12:33AM Little-G wrote: Hi Watson, I don't have any answers for you on this, but I just wanted to give my support.  I'm with LuAnn on the xanax from you GP.  I have a script that never runs out.  It's not as good as valium, but its better than nothing.  Keep that sense of humor going, life gets to "heavy" without it.  We are all here for you!! g
Posts.Title: Lung Mets NOW starting pain on chemo? Watson Mena

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2008 03:56PM Little-G wrote: Hi Liz, No, I haven't found out yet.  I know I should, I'm just burnt out on this.  Mine feels like a bone, its very hard, and feels like that piece of bone is growing.  I have no idea what it is. As far as the lymphatic system..wow...I have no clue.  I have a thing on my leg that looks like a bug bite, its been there forever.  I know I asked a doctor about it way back when, but I can't remember what he thought it was.  It really hasn't changed much, so I'm not to concered with it.  However, since yours is new, and appeared since you were dx with bc (I'm guessing) I would do what I don't do, and ask your onc.  I'm good at giving advice, but not taking it!  :-) g

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2008 10:07PM Little-G wrote: Thanks Binney for the encouragement!  My oncs office did not get back to me today with PT information.  Big surprise there.  I did go get the ultra sound and did go see my GP.  GP said if the ultrasound didn't show anything the next step was an MRI.  Here goes my deductible's again.  But the ultrasound was a cardio-ultrasound, or something like that.  They were looking for blood flow and blood clots, which I thought was strange, since I'm not on any meds?  Well, I should know tomorrow the results of that.  I really like your advice to do something chocolately!!  I will do that!!  g
Posts.Title: Symptom Question Little-G Little-G

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2008 11:33PM Little-G wrote: Hi Liz, No, it feels like a bone and the tech was going to avoid the entire area, and I said, hey what about that lump, so he goes over it and I asked him what it was and he said its bone. ?  I have no idea.  I guess they have reason for wanting that test, but sometimes I wonder.  My GP wants to do an MRI now.  But first I'll go to PT and see what they say.  It's a good thing we all know acronyms or we'd be SOL :-)  g
Posts.Title: Symptom Question Little-G Little-G

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 01:35AM Little-G wrote: E It's been about 2 1/2 years since I had my ooph, and was pre-menopausal.  I was getting shots of zoladex before that for a few months, which put me into menopause.  So..I guess I really don't know when it started.  But it did...and it still does!  Mostly at night now.  Not so much during the day.  None the less, it sucks.  I hope it's not a false sense and you stay feeling as good as you do!

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2008 12:28PM Little-G wrote: Ladies, I wish you all the best of luck!!!  I have a question for all of you that I always wonder, but never have asked.  I have had a back ache for a long time now, most nights I can't sleep and curl into a little ball because of the pain.  I had my neck x-rayed a few weeks ago and the GP said it was arthritis.  He said he wasn't going to call for an MRI as I said I didn't want to do any surgery on it anyway.  My question is, how did you know it was bone mets and not just "normal" back pain?  My back pain is alot and never stops hurting, but its become normal place to me and I just work around it.  But what was the tip off that made you check for mets??  I hope all of you get past this.  g
